awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Competition within and between primate social groups:  Hormonal and behavioral signatures
awd_abstract_narration:
What are the costs and benefits of living in social groups of different sizes? Theory predicts that living in smaller groups should ease competition for resources within groups.  But living in larger groups provides an advantage in competition between groups. These trade-offs between within-group competition (favoring smaller groups) and between-group competition (favoring larger groups) may mean that living in intermediate-sized groups is the best strategy for social species. However, this hypothesis has rarely been tested, and basic questions remain about how competition between individuals and groups affect an individual's energetic condition, and ultimately reproduction and survival. This study will address these questions by analyzing thyroid hormones - a modulator of metabolism and energy balance - in wild primates, in order to understand the relationship between group size, different types of competition, and energetic condition. The research will focus on a wild baboon population in Kenya studied for more than 45 years by the Amboseli Baboon Research Project. To pursue this innovative research direction, investigators will use a repository of approximately 8,000 already-acquired baboon fecal samples collected over a continuous 12-year period from over 200 adult females. Thyroid hormone metabolites will be compared to a rich dataset including information on individual group membership, group size, group movements, reproduction, and life span, among other information, to test the predictions surrounding the benefits of living in groups of varying size.  In concert with the research goals, the investigators will build STEM talent and broaden participation of under-represented groups in behavioral ecology and biological anthropology by: (1) providing employment and training for a full-time research technician; (2) mentoring Stony Brook University graduate and Duke undergraduate students; and (3) developing and implementing a sustainable after school program in behavioral science that targets middle school students from high-needs districts.  This research is co-funded by the Behavioral Systems Program in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Biological Anthropology Program in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences.  


How resource competition affects survival and reproduction in social mammals is a central topic in behavioral ecology and biological anthropology. This research will address this topic directly by empirically evaluating the tension between resource competition within and between social groups in a wild primate population. To do so, the investigators will quantify the concentration of thyroid hormones in approximately 8,000 already-acquired fecal samples from adult female baboons. The central premise is that variation in thyroid hormone concentrations provides a quantifiable index of individual energetic condition, which will vary as a function of competition for energy resources within and between groups. The resulting data will be analyzed in combination with detailed data on individual females and on social groups. Individual-level data will include social status, age, reproductive state, diet, and agonistic interactions; group-level data will include group size, group-level ranging patterns, intergroup encounters, and group stability. The research aims are to: (1) enhance our existing biological validation of fecal thyroid hormone analysis; (2) quantify the energetic consequences of social rank and group size; (3) assess the energetic predictors and consequences of changes in group size that occur through group fission events; and (4) understand the relative contributions of energetic versus psychosocial processes to variation in female endocrine profiles. This novel approach, which will provide an unprecedented window into the energetic consequences of social rank and group size, has rarely been applied to the study of wild primates and has never been applied to any project of this scale and scope.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2017, biological anthropologist Peter Ellison wrote “The essence of life can be defined as ‘metabolism in the service of reproduction’. Organisms capture energy from the environment and turn it into more organisms.”  Understanding the challenges that animals face in capturing energy from the environment is not as well understood as it should be, because it is very difficult to accurately measure energy intake or expenditure in the wild. This creates an important gap in our knowledge: without knowledge about how animals face the energetic challenges of living in harsh environments, we lack a complete picture of how different behavioral and physiological strategies have evolved, and we cannot predict how animals will confront changing environments.   


Recent advances in non-invasively measuring thyroid hormones in feces provide an opportunity to assess energetic condition in the wild. In this study, we measured fecal metabolites of thyroid hormone (specifically a compound known as mT3) to understand how female baboons living in the Amboseli ecosystem in southern Kenya face the energetic challenges of a harsh environment. First, we assessed how a female’s activity budget, diet, and mT3 concentrations changed across seasons and across years. We then tested which environmental variables (season, rainfall, and temperature) and behavioral variables (activity budget and diet) predicted mT3 concentrations. Finally, we determined if two important reproductive events – onset of ovarian cycling and conception of an offspring – were preceded by changes in female mT3 concentrations.


We found that the energetic condition of female baboons varied markedly across seasons and years in relation to environmental conditions: within each year, females were in the worst energetic condition in dry seasons and in the best energetic condition in wet seasons. Across years, females were in better energetic condition in years with more rain compared to years with less rain. We also found that female baboons adapted their activity budgets and diets in response to seasonal variation in rainfall and food availability. They ate lower-quality diets and spent more time feeding and less time resting during the long dry season compared to other seasons.  In addition, mT3 concentrations were lower (reflecting relatively poor energetic condition) when females were pregnant and lactating, when they ate lower quality foods, and also when ambient temperature was either unusually hot or unusually cool. In the weeks prior to menarche and cycling resumption, mT3 concentrations increased (reflecting improvements in energetic condition) regardless of the month or season in which cycling started. This pattern indicates that onset of cycling for female baboons responds directly to increases in energetic condition.  


We also examined female energetic condition in the context of pregnancy and lactation when female baboons were carrying sons versus daughters.  Across several primate species, producing sons is more energetically costly than producing daughters, but few studies have directly assessed the energetic condition of mothers raising sons versus daughters. Using measurements of both fecal metabolites of glucocorticoid (fGC) and thyroid hormones (mT3), we tested the hypothesis that maternal hormones will reflect higher energetic costs associated with producing sons than daughters in Amboseli baboons. We predicted that pregnant and lactating mothers raising sons would have lower mT3 and higher fGC concentrations (worse energetic condition) than mothers raising daughters. In contrast to our hypothesis, we found that the mT3 and fGC levels of mothers did not vary with their infant’s sex. However, when we only looked at the highest ranking (alpha) females, we found that, contrary to our expectations, alpha females raising daughters had significantly lower mT3 concentrations during lactation (i.e., were under greater energetic demands) than alpha females raising sons. Our findings suggest that mothers generally expend the same amount of energy into their offspring regardless of sex, but that alpha mothers expend greater energy when producing daughters than sons.

Overall, these findings improve our understanding of how wild animals face energetic challenges, with implications both for understanding evolution and for predicting population dynamics under climate change.
